choices.text: It has a much shorter half life than Naloxone
Combining Naltrexone with psychological interventions provides limited additional benefit over naltrexone alone
Fatal overdose in those who relapse is rare
Prior to giving the drug, patients should be advised of the risk of withdrawal

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding treatment with Naltrexone?
questions.solution:
• Naltrexone has the propensity to cause a severe withdrawal reaction in patients who are either currently taking opioid drugs or who were previously taking opioid drugs and there has not been a sufficient ‘wash-out’ period before administering naltrexone.
  • Evidence for the effectiveness of naltrexone as a treatment for relapse prevention in opioid misusers has been inconclusive.
  • Close monitoring is particularly important when naltrexone is initiated because of the higher risk of fatal overdose at this time. Discontinuation of naltrexone may also be associated with an increase in inadvertent overdose from illicit opioids.
  • people taking naltrexone often experience adverse effects of unease (dysphoria), depression and insomnia, which can lead to relapse to illicit opioid use while on naltrexone treatment, or failure to continue on treatment. The dysphoria may be caused by either withdrawal from illicit drugs or by the naltrexone treatment itself, emphasizing the importance of prescribing naltrexone as part of a care program that includes psychosocial therapy and general support.

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 4, page 496

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate drug for a depressed lady who is pregnant?
questions.solution:
Of the above mentioned antidepressants sertraline appears to be safest due to its least placental exposure.

Even though SSRIs appear not to be major teratogens, paroxetine has been found to be linked to cardiac malformations particularly after high exposure in the first trimester.

SSRIs have also been associated with reduced gestational age, spontaneous abortion, gestational hypertension and pre eclampsia.

Venlafaxine is also associated with cardiac defects, anencephaly and cleft palate, neonatal withdrawal and postpartum hemorrhage.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 7, pregnancy and breastfeeding, page 687

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic gentleman was brought to A & E with nausea, vomiting, lethargy and muscle cramps. He has been diagnosed with depression and has been started on Fluoxetine recently. What is the most likely metabolic complication?
questions.solution:
Above mentioned vignette describes a patient who has developed hyponatremia following treatment with fluoxetine. Most antidepressants have been associated with hyponatremia however serotonergic drugs are more likely to cause hyponatremia than noradrenergic drugs. The risk is highest in the first 2-4 weeks of starting antidepressant and diminishes over time until by 3-6 months. Medical comorbidities such as hypothyroidism, diabetes, COPD, hypertension, head injury, cancer increases the risk of developing hyponatremia.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 3, depression and anxiety disorders, page 393

choices.text: There is an HLA association with REM sleep behaviour disorder
Sleep latency of more than 10 min on overnight polysomnography is characteristic of narcolepsy
REM sleep behaviour disorder can precede future movement disorders

questions.text: Research and investigations into sleep disorders have suggested that:
questions.solution:
• REM sleep Behaviour disorders can precede future movement disorders.
  • Stimulants such as modafinil are 1stline treatment for narcolepsy
  • To diagnose narcolepsy as per DSM 5 the REM sleep latency should be less than or equal to 15 minutes in nocturnal sleep polysomnography or multiple sleep latency showing a mean sleep latency less than or equal to 8 minutes and two or more sleep onset REM periods should be present
  • Hypocretins are not different from orexin. Hypocretin deficiency in CSF is seen in narcolepsy.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 16, normal sleep and sleep wake disorders, page 547-550, 556

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to a cardiac intensive care unit after suffering a heart attack. Twenty-four hours after admission, the consultation psychiatrist is called in to make an evaluation because the patient is trying to sign himself out against medical advice. When the psychiatrist enters the patient's hospital room, she finds him getting dressed and yelling at the top of his lungs, 'I won't be treated in this manner! How dare you!' The patient does agree to sit down and speak with the psychiatrist, however. He tells the psychiatrist that staff members are simply rude and do not treat him 'in the manner to which he is accustomed He cannot understand why the staff will not bring food up from an outside cafeteria for him because the food in the hospital is so bad. He asks the psychiatrist whether, after the interview, she will get some food for him, and he becomes angry when she declines. Wife reports that patient has so far changed multiple jobs as he always gets into fights with his superiors and colleagues and always feels that he cannot work under someone less skilled than him. Wife says that before starting his business he did not work for 5 years even though they were facing serious financial crisis and rejected multiple job offers with appropriate salary and position. The most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder have a heightened sense of self-importance, lack of empathy, and grandiose feelings of uniqueness. Underneath, however, their self-esteem is fragile and vulnerable to even minor criticism.
  • Persons with paranoid personality disorder have long-standing suspiciousness and mistrust of persons in general. They refuse responsibility for their feelings and assign responsibility to others. They are often hostile, irritable, and angry.
  • Persons with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder typically are emotionally constricted, orderly, perseverative, stubborn, and indecisive. The essential feature of the disorder is a pervasive pattern of perfectionism and inflexibility.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, chapter 19, Personality Disorders, pg 1780

choices.text: Fourth ventricle to central canal of spinal cord

questions.text: The foramen of Monro connects
questions.solution:
The foramen of Monro (also known as the interventricular foramen) is part of the ventricular system and the connection between the third ventricle and the lateral ventricles. It allows for the flow of CSF, and, therefore, if blocked or effaced, causes a reduction in CSF flow from the lateral ventricles despite no associated reduction in CSF production from the choroid plexus.

Reference: PG notes in psychiatry, Cijo Alex, 2nd edition, chapter 6, Neuroanatomy, page 65

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with bipolar I disorder has been adequately maintained on lithium. His most recent serum lithium level was 0.8 mEq/ L. He has a variety of medical problems for which he takes several medications. He now presents with pressured speech, racing thoughts, increased energy, and reduced need for sleep. His serum lithium level is 0.3 mEq/L. His wife reports that the patient has been adherent to his medication regimen, but she began to notice a change 2 weeks after his primary care physician started him on a new medication. What was the most likely class of medication added to his regimen?
questions.solution:
In the above mentioned vignette, patient is seen having a relapse of manic episode with reduction in serum lithium levels. Of the above mentioned drugs, theophylline is known to reduce serum lithium levels while ACE inhibitors, NSAIDS and thiazide all increase serum lithium levels.

While Carbamazepine is associated with increased toxicity.



Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 2, Bipolar disorder, page 254

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is seen for an initial outpatient psychiatric assessment. Her husband says that increasingly over the past 2 years she has seemed less like her usual outgoing self. She has been increasingly apathetic and uninterested in her usual activities, and more recently she has behaved inappropriately in social interactions, making unusual comments and returning home with items that do not belong to her. Recently, her husband has had to begin helping her dress in the morning, and he notes that she is occasionally incontinent of urine. On mental status examination, her affect is blunted and her speech is sparse, although she does not report specific psychotic symptoms or changes in mood. She knows the year and the season but not the month or date, and she has particular difficulty in naming objects. MRI shows prominent frontal and some temporal atrophy with relative sparing of other cortical regions. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Pick’s Disease(frontotemporal dementia) is characterized by personality and behavioural changes with relative preservation of other cognitive functions in the early stages. Apathy, lack of interest in usual activities and inappropriate social behavior is also seen. In contrast to parito temporal distribution of pathological findings in Alzheimer’s disease, Pick’s disease is characterized by a preponderance of atrophy in the frontotemporal region.
  • Lewy body disease is a dementia clinically similar to Alzheimer's disease and often characterized by hallucinations, parkinsonian features, and extrapyramidal signs Lewy inclusion bodies are found in the cerebral cortex. The exact incidence is unknown. These patients often have Capgras syndrome (reduplicative paramnesia) as part of the clinical picture.
  • The dementia of Huntington's disease exhibits psychomotor slowing and difficulty with complex tasks, but memory, language, and insight remain relatively intact in the early and middle stages of the illness. As the disease progresses, however, the dementia becomes complete; the features distinguishing it from dementia of the Alzheimer's type are the high incidence of depression and psychosis in addition to the classic choreoathetoid movement disorder.
  • As with huntington’s, parkinson’s disease is also associated with dementia and depression. An estimated 20 to 30 percent of patients with Parkinson's disease have dementia, and an additional 30 to 40 percent have measurable impairment in cognitive abilities. The slow movements of persons with Parkinson's disease are paralleled in the slow thinking of some affected patients, a feature that clinicians may refer to as bradyphrenia.
  • Three forms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease exist: sporadic (most common), familial and variant CJD (vCJD - related to bovine spongiform encephalopathy). It has a relatively short course and poor prognosis. Patients surviving more than 6 months to year may have some degree of generalized cerebral atrophy.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, chapter 3.2 Dementia

questions.text: Narcolepsy is characterized by which of the following signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Narcolepsy is a condition characterized by excessive sleepiness, as well as auxiliary symptoms that represent the intrusion of aspects of REM sleep into the waking state The sleep attacks of narcolepsy represent episodes of irresistible sleepiness, leading to perhaps 10 to 20 minutes of sleep, after which the patient feels refreshed, at least briefly. They can occur at inappropriate times (e.g., while eating, talking, or driving and during sex). The REM sleep includes hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations, cataplexy, and sleep paralysis. The appearance of REM sleep within 10 minutes of sleep onset (sleep-onset REM periods) is also considered evidence of narcolepsy. The disorder can be dangerous because it can lead to automobile and industrial accidents.
  • Cataplexy is defined as brief episodes of sudden bilateral loss of muscle tone with maintained consciousness which are precipitated by laughter or joking. While in children it is characterized by spontaneous grimaces or jaw opening episodes with tongue thrusting or a global hypotonia without any obvious emotional trigger.
  • While Catalepsy is a feature of catatonia characterized by passive induction of a posture that is held against gravity.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 16.2, sleep wake disorders, page 547

questions.text: A 27-year-old man has a long-standing history of marked discomfort in social situations and avoids group discussions, parties, dating, and speaking at meetings. He has a history of binge alcohol use, particularly when he has to engage in social activities as he fears being criticized by people. The class of medication preferred for treatment of this patient would be:
questions.solution:
• The above case describes a patient with marked discomfort in social situations especially situations that involve scrutiny or contact with strangers, due to fear of “ embarrassing himself”, which is suggestive of social anxiety disorder.
  • Social anxiety disorder or social phobia is characterized by intense and persistent fear of an object or situation. People with this condition are fearful of embarrassing themselves in social situations i.e., social gatherings, oral presentations, meeting new people etc. The fear is of the embarrassment that may occur in the situation rather than the situation itself.
  • Both psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy are useful in treating social anxiety disorder. Combination of both produce better results than either therapy alone.
  • Effective medications are SSRI( selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) – first line, Benzodiazepines, venlafaxine and buspirone.
  • Psychotherapy usually involves a combination of behavioural and cognitive methods including cognitive retraining, desensitization, rehearsal during sessions and a range of homework assignments.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 9.5 social anxiety disorder, page 405

questions.text: A 35-year-old nurse is admitted to the medical service with numerous ecchymoses on her body and a complaint of tarry stools. Her prothrombin time was 4 INR (international normalized prothrombin ratio) units (normal, 0.78-1.22). Several days after admission her prothrombin time was normal. A medical workup failed to identify the cause of her abnormal clotting time. Her stool was weakly positive for blood. Four days after admission, more ecchymoses appeared and her prothrombin time was again elevated. The patient expressed concern that she might have leukemia and inquired if she would need a bone marrow biopsy. On the fifth day of admission, a warfarin pill was found beneath her bed. The patient signed out of the hospital that evening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Patients with factitious disorder simulate, induce, or aggravate illness to receive medical attention, regardless of whether or not they are ill. Thus, they may inflict painful, deforming, or even life-threatening injury on themselves, their children, or other dependents. The primary motivation is not avoidance of duties, financial gain, or anything concrete. The motivation is simply to receive medical care and to partake in the medical system.
  • Some clues that should trigger suspicion for factitious disorder are unusual, dramatic presentation of symptoms that may defy conventional medical of psychiatric understanding, lack of response to treatment, some medical background, eagerness to undergo procedures or hospitalizations, extensive medical history of multiple surgeries or investigations. pointed or accusatory questioning may lead to flight from hospital.
  • Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by 6 or more months of general and non delusional preoccupation with one or more somatic symptoms, fear of having a serious disease and marked anxiety secondary to that. However there is no feigning of symptoms in order to gain medical attention.
  • Malingering must be distinguished from factitious disorder. malingerers have obvious recognizable environmental goal such as avoiding work, responsibilities, evade police, secure financial compensation or just to obtain free bed etc. these patients stop producing symptoms when there are no longer profitable or too risky.
  • Illness anxiety disorder even though appears similar to somatic symptom disorder, there are few or no somatic symptoms and persons are primarily concerned with the idea they are ill. They are more preoccupied with knowing the diagnosis while in somatic symptoms disorder patients are preoccupied with the symptoms
  • Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by preoccupation with one or more perceived defects in appearance that are not observed by others or are slight to others and multiple efforts to either correct or camouflage the perceived defects.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 13 psychosomatic medicine

questions.text: A physician elects to treat a depressed patient with imipramine. Four days after the start of treatment, the physician receives a call from the emergency department reporting that the patient has fallen. The staff report that the patient stood up quickly after being in bed overnight, felt dizzy, and then lost consciousness, falling to the floor. Examination reveals a pulse of 76 bpm; blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg lying and 84/46 mm Hg standing. An electrocardiogram is unremarkable. Which of the following best explains the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• In the above mentioned case, the patient developed orthostatic hypotension following initiation of imipramine which is due to alpha adrenergic blockade.
  • Alpha adrenergic blockade may cause dizziness, sedation, hypotension.
  • Cholinergic blockade may explain dry mouth, blurred vision and constipation.
  • While histamine blockade may explain sedation and weight gain.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias and seizures especially in overdose are due to ion channel blockade.

Reference: Stahl’s essential psychopharmacology, prescriber’s guide, 6th edition, imipramine,page 342

questions.text: Minimum Duration needed to diagnose a manic episode in absence of hospitalization as per DSM 5?
questions.solution:
As per DSM 5, Manic episode is characterized by a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased goal directed activity or energy, lasting everyday nearly all the time, that may last atleast upto 7 days or less if hospitalization is required.

During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behaviour:

  1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
  2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
  3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
  4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
  5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed.
  6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation (i.e., purposeless non-goal directed activity).
  7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments)

Reference: Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, 5th edition, page 124

questions.text: Which of the following agent is not used in the treatment of alcohol use disorder?
questions.solution:
All of the above mentioned agents are used in the treatment of alcohol use disorder except Buprenorphine.

Buprenorphine a partial Mu agonist is used in the treatment of opioid use disorder.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 4, addictions and substance misuse

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic drugs has the least potential to cause hyperprolactinemia?
questions.solution:
Second generation antipsychotics, due to their dopamine blockade action on tuberoinfundibular pathway, can cause elevation in the prolactin levels. As dopamine inhibits prolactin, dopamine antagonists can elevate prolactin levels. Of the above mentioned second generation antipsychotic medications, aripiprazole has the least potency to cause hyperprolactinemia. While amisulpride, risperidone, paliperidone, sulpride are the most notorious in causing hyperprolactinemia.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 1, schizophrenia and related psychosis, page 168

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication to start Bupropion?
questions.solution:
• Bupropion is a norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor(NDRI).
  • Indications for bupropion use are as follow
    • Major depressive disorder
    • Seasonal affective disorder
    • Nicotine addiction
    • Bipolar depression
    • ADHD
    • Sexual dysfunction
  • Bupropion is associated with reduction in seizure threshold and so should be avoided in patients with history of seizure disorders.

Reference: Stahl’s essential psychopharmacology, prescriber’s guide, 6th edition, bupropion, page 107

questions.text: A 42 year old man with a long standing history of Alcohol use disorder decides to seek help for his alcohol problems after his wife threatens to leave him. The treating psychiatrist explains the patient pros and cons of various treatment options available and they decide on one medication to treat his dependence however patient has been advised to refrain from using alcohol or any other alcohol containing products during the course of his medication to avoid serious adverse effects such as Nausea, flushing, Headache, chest pain, palpitations etc. which of the following drugs has been suggested to the patient?
questions.solution:
Disulfiram is one of the anticraving agents used in the treatment of Alcohol use disorder.

Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor that interferes with the metabolism of alcohol by producing a marked increase in blood acetaldehyde concentration. The accumulation of acetaldehyde (to a level up to 10 times higher than occurs in the normal metabolism of alcohol) produces a wide array of unpleasant reactions, called the disulfiram-alcohol reaction, characterized by nausea, throbbing headache, vomiting, hypertension, flushing, sweating, thirst, dyspnea, tachycardia, chest pain, vertigo, and blurred vision. The reaction occurs almost immediately after the ingestion of one alcoholic drink and may last from 30 minutes to 2 hours. because of the severe physical reactions the drug causes after drinking, disulfiram is suitable for only highly motivated and strictly supervised patients.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 29, psychopharmacological treatment, page 967

questions.text: The parents of a 14-year-old boy bring him to a clinic because he has been refusing to go to school. In elementary and middle school, he was in a special education class for mildly mentally retarded students. When he has been at school, he ruminates about 'something really bad' happening to his mother or father. Recently, he has been awakening with nightmares that his parents have been killed. His parents have had to stay with their son in order for him to get back to sleep. His medical history is significant for strabismus and scoliosis. Physical examination reveals a long face with prominent ears and jaw, a high arched palate, hyperextensible finger joints, macro orchidism, and flat feet. This boy's overall presentation is most consistent with:
questions.solution:
Fragile x syndrome is an x linked dominant disorder caused by mutation in FMR1 gene associated with CGG trinucleotide repeats.

Affected individuals have a range of developmental problems including learning disability, mild intellectual disability, delayed development of speech and language.

Physically they usually have Long face, large ears, midface hypoplasia, high arched palate, short stature, macro orchidism, mitral valve prolapse, joint laxity, strabismus.

Hyperactivity, inattention, anxiety, stereotypies, social avoidance, shyness, irritability are also seen in affected individuals.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 31, child psychiatry, page 1130

questions.text: A female patient reveals during a psychotherapy session says that she does not enjoy sexual intercourse. She states that she is aroused by her partner but has sharp pains throughout intercourse. She cannot relax and enjoy sex and has begun to avoid sex because of the anticipation of the pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Dyspareunia is recurrent or persistent genital pain occurring before, during, or after intercourse. Dyspareunia is related to, and often coincides with, vaginismus. Chronic pelvic pain is a common complaint in women with a history of rape or childhood sexual abuse. Painful coitus can result from tension and anxiety about the sex act that cause women to involuntarily contract their pelvic floor muscles. The pain is real and makes intercourse unpleasant or unbearable. Anticipation of further pain may cause women to avoid coitus altogether
  • Female orgasmic disorder, sometimes called inhibited female orgasm or anorgasmia, is defined as the recurrent or persistent inhibition of female orgasm, as manifested by the recurrent delay in, or absence of orgasm after a normal sexual excitement phase that a clinician judges to be adequate in focus, intensity, and duration-in short, a woman's inability to achieve orgasm by masturbation or coitus
  • Sexual masochism and sadism are paraphilias. While in sexual masochism, individual has sexual fantasies or recurrent urges of being humiliated, beaten, bound or otherwise made to suffer, sexual sadism refers to recurrent and intense sexual arousal from suffering of the other individual.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 17, human sexuality and sexual dysfunctions

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is referred for evaluation because he is having 'temper tantrums' in school. He cannot sit still, constantly disrupts the class, runs out in the hall without permission and refuses to obey directives from the teacher. He frequently fights with his peers, and if he does not get what he wants, he yells, screams, throws objects, and flails about on the floor. Educational testing reveals borderline intellectual functioning and significant delays in reading, writing, spelling, end mathematics. On physical examination, the boy is noted to be in the fifth percentile for head circumference. He has short palpebral fissures, a thin upper lip, and a smooth philtrum. The boy was most likely exposed to which of the following drugs in utero?
questions.solution:
Maternal consumption of alcohol during pregnancy results in fetal alcohol syndrome in children.

These children have Microcephaly, short stature, midface hypoplasia, short palpebral fissure, thin upper lip, retrognathia in infancy, micrognathia in adolescence, hypoplastic long or smooth philtrum.

They also suffer from Mild to moderate intellectual disability, irritability, inattention, memory impairment.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 31, child psychiatry, page 1131

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia is hospitalized and treated with haloperidol. The patient becomes distressed, has a temperature of 103 C F and has labile blood pressure. Physical examination reveals hypertonicity, diaphoresis, and tachycardia. Laboratory studies reveal a creatine kinase of 55,000 IU/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during the course of antipsychotic treatment. The motor and behavioral symptoms include muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agitation. The autonomic symptoms include hyperthermia, diaphoresis, and increased pulse and blood pressure. Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatinine phosphokinase, liver enzymes, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria, occasionally associated with renal failure.
  • Concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAOI, Ltryptophan, or lithium or other serotonergic drugs can raise plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels, producing a constellation of symptoms called serotonin syndrome. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome of serotonin overstimulation comprises, in order of appearance as the condition worsens, (1) diarrhea; (2) restlessness; (3) extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability with possible rapid fluctuations in vital signs; (4) myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity; and (5) delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death if left untreated.
  • Malignant hyperthermia refers to a serious adverse reaction to some of the anesthetic agents
  • Even though anticholinergic syndrome may have similar findings to NMS, history of haloperidol administration and lab findings of elevated CK are more suggestive of NMS.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 29, psychopharmacological treatment, page 925, 1020

questions.text: Which of the following is the best medication treatment for premature ejaculation?
questions.solution:
• Almost all the antidepressants have dose dependent reversible sexual side effects.
  • Of the antidepressants SSRIs are more notorious in terms of their potency to cause sexual dysfunctions such as loss of libido, anorgasmia and delayed ejaculation.
  • However the same adverse effect can sometimes be used as a therapeutic measure to treat premature ejaculation.
  • Paroxetine in this case can be used to treat premature ejaculation due to their ability to cause delayed ejaculation.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14thedition, chapter 3, depression and anxiety disorder, page 405

choices.text: Four or more mood episodes in a year
Four or more mood episodes in a month
Eight or more manic episodes in a year
Eight of more mood episodes in 2 years

questions.text: Rapid cycling bipolar disorder refers to
questions.solution:
As per DSM 5 individuals with bipolar 1 disorder with four or more mood episodes(major depressive, manic or hypomanic) in a year are considered as having rapid cycling bipolar disorder.

Reference: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of mental disorders V, fifth edition, page 130

questions.text: The parents of a 7-year-old boy express concern about his bed-wetting. The boy seems well adjusted, and the family has developed a non stigmatizing system to care for his bed and personal hygiene. He has no medical problems. After explaining the natural history of enuresis, the most reasonable initial approach would be to:
questions.solution:
• enuresis is often self limited and a high rate of spontaneous remission is observed in childhood. However in many cases a timely intervention is necessary as enuresis can cause functional impairment and loss of self esteem and confidence over time.
  • The first step in management is however to review appropriate toilet training.
  • Record keeping, star chart, restricting fluids before bedtime, night lifting to toilet train all some useful toilet training techniques.
  • Bell and pad technique works on the principle of classical conditioning. An alarm is attached to child’s underwear and it awakens the child as soon as the voiding starts.
  • Pharmacological measures include desmopressin or reboxetine.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 31, child psychiatry, page 1216

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was unexpectedly terminated from her job. Two months later she presents tearfully with depressed mood and occasional feelings of hopelessness; she still feels stressed by the loss of her job. She has no prior history of depression, is not suicidal, has not had changes in appetite, weight, sleep, or energy level, and still gets pleasure from family and hobbies. Which of the following diagnoses would be the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Adjustment disorders are characterized by an emotional response to a stressful event. Typically, the stressor involves financial issues, a medical illness, or relationship problem. The symptom complex that develops may involve anxious or depressive affect or may present with a disturbance of conduct. By definition, the symptoms must begin within 3 months of the stressor.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 11.2, trauma and stress related disorders, page 446

questions.text: The clinical sign that best differentiates delirium from dementia is:
questions.solution:
• Delirium is characterized by an acute decline in both the level of consciousness and cognition with particular impairment in attention. The hallmark symptom of delirium is an impairment of consciousness, usually occurring in association with global impairments of cognitive functions. Abnormalities of mood, perception, and behavior are common psychiatric symptoms. Tremor, asterixis, nystagmus, incoordination, and urinary incontinence are common neurological symptoms. Classically, delirium has a sudden onset (hours or days), a brief and fluctuating course, and rapid improvement when the causative factor is identified and eliminated, but each of these characteristic features can vary in individual patient.
  • While Dementia refers to a disease process marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. The cognitive deficits in dementia represent a decline from a previous level of functioning. Dementia involves multiple cognitive domains and cognitive deficits cause significant impairment in social and occupational functioning and impairment in the functions of daily living.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 21, neurocognitive disorders, 697, 704

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with a 2-week history of difficulty sleeping, hearing voices, and problems with thinking. She was fearful and suspicious, and talked about evil alien forces out in the world. Some of her relatives have had 'nervous breakdowns' requiring hospitalization. Further evaluation revealed that the woman had been raped about 3 weeks earlier. However, she has no recollection of the event. One week after initial presentation, her symptoms have disappeared and she has returned to normal functioning. The most likely diagnosis at this time is:
questions.solution:
Brief psychotic disorder is defined as a psychotic condition that involves the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, which lasts 1 day or more but less than 1 month. Remission is full, and the individual returns to the premorbid level of functioning. Brief psychotic disorder is an acute and transient psychotic syndrome usually in response to a stressor.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th'edition, chapter 7: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders, page 339

questions.text: Which of the following medications has been shown to be most effective in reducing suicidal behaviors in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder?
questions.solution:
Clozapine has shown some advantage over other antipsychotics in terms of suicidality in schizophrenic patients.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 7: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders, page 314

questions.text: The most effective behavior therapy technique used in the treatment of compulsions of obsessive-compulsive disorder is:
questions.solution:
• The principle behavior approach used in the treatment of OCD is exposure and response prevention. Exposure and response prevention commonly known as ERP includes exposing the patient to obsessive thoughts, images, objects, impulses in a controlled manner and preventing any neutralizing compulsions.
  • Positive, negative reinforcement, punishment are all principles of operant conditioning, however not used in the treatment of OCD.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 10, obsessive compulsive and related disorders, page 425

questions.text: The parents of a 5-year-old boy bring their child to a clinic with the complaint that he frequently awakens during the early part of the night screaming; he looks terrified, his pupils are dilated, and he hyperventilates. He is also sweating, agitated, and confused, and he cannot be comforted. When fully awakened, the child has no recall of the event. This presentation is most consistent with:
questions.solution:
• Sleep terror disorder is an arousal in the first third of the night during deep NREM (stages 3 and 4) sleep. It is characterized by a sudden arousal with intense fearfulness. They usually begin with a piercing scream or cry and are accompanied by behavioral manifestations of intense anxiety bordering on panic. Autonomic and behavioral correlates of fright typically mark the experience. An individual experiencing a sleep terror usually sits up in bed, is unresponsive to stimuli, and, if awakened, is confused or disoriented. Vocalizations may occur, but they usually are incoherent. They have no recollection of the episode the next day.
  • In contrast nightmares are terrifying or frightening dreams that awakens the person and usually occurs during REM sleep. There is no amnesia for the episode.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 16, normal sleep and sleep wake disorders, page 556

questions.text: The practice of obtaining informed consent from an individual prior to initiating any treatment fulfills which of the following ethical principles?
questions.solution:
Autonomy - respecting patients' wishes and freedom of choice

Non maleficence embodies the ethical principle of avoiding harm.

Beneficence - acting in patients' best interest

Justice refers to fairness in the distribution, treating problems equally, with equitable distribution of resources to the needy.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 36: Forensic Psychiatry and Ethics in Psychiatry, page 1392- 1393

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has a long history of difficulty with driving because she worries that she might hit a car or a person accidentally. She also worries excessively about her son getting hurt or attacked when he goes out. She also reports being anxious a lot while cooking thinking she might not be able to cook well and on time for her kids, however this has never happened. Her husband can often reassure her easily. Which of the following diagnoses is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
• Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety and worry occurring for atleast 6 months about a number of activities such as work, family, finances etc which causes significant impairment in person's social and occupational life. The anxiety is associated with physical symptoms such as restlessness, fatigability, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbance etc.
  • The scenario mentions that patient can be reassured easily by the husband, goes against delusional disorder
  • Agoraphobia refers to marked anxiety or fear about places from where the escape would be difficult in case of emergency.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 9.6, anxiety disorders, page 407

questions.text: A consultation is requested for a 20-year-old man because of a gradual onset of behavioral symptoms that include irritability, aggression, and personality change. Associated findings include mild jaundice, dysarthria, and choreiform movements. The consultant psychiatrist also notices a golden-brown discoloration of the cornea. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Wilson's disease is a rare inherited disorder of copper metabolism, resulting in the toxic accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, and other organs. Individuals with Wilson's disease have mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound copper-transporting adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase). Deficiency of this protein impairs copper excretion into the bile and copper incorporation into ceruloplasmin, leading to its rapid degradation.
  • Hepatic disease may present as hepatitis, cirrhosis, or hepatic decompensation. In other pts, neurologic or psychiatric disturbances are the first clinical sign and are always accompanied by Kayser-Fleischer rings (corneal deposits of copper). Dystonia, incoordination, or tremor may be present, and dysarthria and dysphagia are common. Autonomic disturbances also may be present. Microscopic hematuria is common. In about 5% of pts, the first manifestation may be primary or secondary amenorrhea or repeated spontaneous abortions.

Reference: Harrison's manual of medicine, 20th edition, section 13, wilson's disease, page 976

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents with weakness, fatigue, somnolence, and depression. Her husband has also noticed that there has been some cognitive slowing and her voice is hoarse. Which of the following endocrine disorders is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism presents with fatigue, somnolence, weakness, dry skin, brittle hair, cold intolerance, and hoarse speech. Depression is common, and cognitive slowing can occur. Hypoparathyroidism and hyperparathyroidism can both result in anxiety, irritability, or depression. Hyperparathyroidism is commonly accompanied by weakness and anorexia, whereas hypoparathyroidism has mainly neuromuscular signs such as spasms, tetany, and hyperreflexia. Pheochromocytoma results in palpitations, panic attacks, headaches, and hypertension.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 8, mood disorders, page 351

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an instrumental activity of daily living that becomes impaired in the mild to moderate stages of dementia?
questions.solution:
Instrumental activities of daily living include more complex daily tasks such as managing finances (e.g., writing checks), grocery shopping, preparing meals, keeping track of current events, remembering appointments, managing medications, using the phone, and traveling (e.g., taking the bus). A person's ability to manage these activities independently generally becomes impaired in the mild to moderate stages of dementia. As dementia progresses, the more basic activities of daily living (ADLs) become impaired, and most people need assistance with them. ADLs include feeding, dressing, toileting, grooming, physical ambulation and transferring, and bathing.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 21, neurocognitive disorders, page 712-718

questions.text: Priapism is associated with the use of which medication?
questions.solution:
One of the rare however dangerous side effect of trazodone is priapism.

Reference: Stahl's essential psychopharmacology, prescriber's guide, 6th edition, trazodone, page 742

questions.text: Mr Edward Hughes is a 23-year-old man with autism spectrum disorder and moderate intellectual impairment. He lives in a placement and has been demonstrating aggressive behaviour over the last several months. Attempts to identify the cause of his distress or address his behaviour via non-pharmacological methods have been fruitless. Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Risperidone and Aripiprazole have the greatest evidence base for the pharmacological management of aggression in ASD. Other second- and first-generation antipsychotics, antiepileptic medications, lithium, naltrexone and N-acetylcysteine have also been used although with less evidence being available for these agents.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 31.5, autism spectrum disorder, page 1162

questions.text: A parrot was given a new cage. When the parrot touched a lever in the cage, it received an electric shock. It did not touch the lever again. The learning process that has occurred here is;
questions.solution:
In behaviourism, punishment refers to procedures that weaken or decreases a particular behavior in contrast to reinforcement in which application(positive reinforcement) or removal(negative reinforcement) of a stimulus increases a behaviour. Punishment can be either negative or positive, depending on the nature of the consequence.

Positive punishment - application of an aversive stimuli to reduce the behavior (as in the above example). Here the parrot reduced the behavior( touching the lever) due to application of aversive stimuli( shock)

Negative punishment - potential loss or postponement of desirable stimuli leads to decrease in behavior (for eg parents restricting their kids's outing leads to reduction in them hitting their younger siblings)

Reference: Psychology by Robert A Baron, Girishwar Misra, 5th edition, chapter 5, learning, page

questions.text: A 55-year-old heavy alcoholic was admitted to the medical ward after sustaining a major fall. He has severe Anterograde amnesia and extensive retrograde memory loss. However his working memory and procedural memory are unimpaired. What is his most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Korsakoff's syndrome: It is a form of an amnesic syndrome often occurring in patients with a history of severe alcohol abuse due to thiamine deficiency. The patient may have severe Anterograde amnesia and extensive retrograde memory loss. This retrograde memory loss includes autobiographical memory loss with relative sparing of the most distant memories. Working memory and procedural memory are unimpaired. The pathological features are mostly found in paraventricular and periaqueductal grey matter, thalamus and mamillary bodies.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition ,Chapter 20: Substance Use and Addictive Disorders, page 632

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is associated with military prisoners?
questions.solution:
In 1897, a neurologist called Sigbert Ganser noted a syndrome of approximate answers to simple questions, hallucinations, clouding of consciousness, and somatic conversion in three prisoners. This syndrome is variously described as Ganser syndrome, prison psychosis. It is rare but seen more commonly among prisoners.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 12, dissociative disorders, page 463

questions.text: Postpartum psychosis is most commonly associated with
questions.solution:
The prevalence of postpartum psychosis in the general population is 1-2 per 1,000 childbirths, and the rate is 100 times higher in women with bipolar disorder or a previous history of postpartum psychosis. Bipolar disorder and, to a lesser extent, schizophrenia have elevated prevalence in postpartum psychosis

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition ,Chapter 27, psychiatry and reproductive medicine, page 840

questions.text: What drug should be immediately given to the mother and the neonate after delivery when valproate or carbamazepine is used during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
During pregnancy, if valproate or carbamazepine is prescribed; Prophylactic folic acid should be used. Prophylactic Vitamin K should be given mother and neonate after delivery when valproate or carbamazepine is used to prevent bleeding.

Reference: Stahl's essential psychopharmacology, prescriber's guide, 6th edition, Valproate, page 777, carbamazepine page 125

questions.text: A depressed patient on the ward complained of total inability to experience pleasure. What is the term used to denote this type of pathological change in mood?
questions.solution:
Anhedonia: Total inability to experience pleasure. It is divided into physical anhedonia e.g. No appreciation of beauty of sunset (not enjoying the 'feast' - the outcome) and social anhedonia e.g. no enjoyment of company of friends (not enjoying the 'hunt' - the process). Anhedonia occurs in depression and schizophrenia

Reference- Fish's clinical psychopathology, 3rd edition, chapter 5, disorders of emotion, page 65

questions.text: La belle indifference is typically seen in
questions.solution:
La belle indifference is the inappropriate lack of concern about a deficit or disability that typically appears in conversion disorders. It is also seen in medical illnesses such as stroke . It is rare and non-specific symptom, and of no diagnostic value. La belle indifference is more commonly observed in adults, and is rare in children and adolescents (as few as 8%). Children and adolescents may typically express fear and hopelessness regarding their lack of voluntary control over their neurological symptoms.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition , Chapter 13, psychosomatic medicine, page 473-477

questions.text: A patient at your clinic reports, 'When I heard the railway station master's whistle, I knew that there was a plot to attack me.' This is called
questions.solution:
The delusional perception is the attribution of a new meaning, usually in the sense of self-reference, to a normally perceived object. The new meaning cannot be understood as arising from the patient's affective state or previous attitudes. Schneider emphasised the importance of this symptom's 'two membered ness', as there is a link from the perceived object to the subject's perception of this object, and a second link to the new significance of this perception.

Reference- Fish's clinical psychopathology, 3rd edition, chapter 3, disorders of thought and speech, page 39-40

questions.text: A patient withdrawing from alcohol sees small Chinese soldiers marching on his carpet. This phenomenon is called
questions.solution:
Lilliputian hallucinations are visual hallucinations of diminutive persons or animals. Unlike the usual organic visual hallucinations, these may be accompanied by pleasure and amusement. Usually seen in Alcohol withdrawal states(delirium Tremens)

Reference- Fish's clinical psychopathology, 3rd edition, chapter 2, Disorders of perception, page 23-24

questions.text: A woman wakes up at 6am every morning, does 1 hour of vacuuming, prepares her list for the day and arrives at work 30 minutes before the start time. At work, she is always ahead of her schedule and always plans things well in advance. She expects her junior colleagues to be at her standard. What is the correct term to describe this scenario?
questions.solution:
• Unless there is some evidence of psychosocial dysfunction, this must be considered as normal.
  • OCD is repetitive, intrusive, time consuming and distressing thoughts, images, urges or preoccupations which causes significant distress to the patient and are often followed by repetitive behaviours or mental acts aimed at preventing anxiety . pure obsessions without compulsions or pure compulsions without obsessions are also seen.
  • Persons with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder are preoccupied with rules, regulations, orderliness, neatness, details, and the achievement of perfection. They insist that rules be followed rigidly and cannot tolerate what they consider infractions. Accordingly, they lack flexibility and are intolerant. However the major difference between OCD and OCPD is that OCPD is ego syntonic while OCD is ego dystonic.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition , Chapter 22, personality disorders, page 756, chapter 10, obsessive compulsive and related disorders, page 418

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady in your inpatient unit covers her head with a veil. She claims that other people can come to know what she thinks. The most likely description is
questions.solution:
Patients may complain that their thoughts are no longer private but are accessible to others. This is associated with thought broadcasting or thought diffusion (also a first-rank symptom) and is best classified as a disorder of thought rather than a hallucinatory experience, since there is no necessary implication that thoughts must first be heard.

Reference- Fish's clinical psychopathology, 3rd edition, chapter 2, Disorders of perception, page 21-22

questions.text: A 55-year-old married lady is a mother of three girls who were all raised by her. All are now grown up and her last daughter left home to study recently. Now the mother feels lonely and despondent. Which one of the following terms describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Empty nest distress or empty nest syndrome refers to the feeling of loneliness when children leave home which usually occurs during latter part of middle age. Midlife transition or crisis occurs around age 40 to 45, when individuals become acutely aware of their limitations with their previous goals and re evaluating their life. Downshifting refers to voluntary opting out of pressurised career and giving up well-paid job for more fulfilling life (anti-urbanism)

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition , Chapter 27, psychiatry and reproductive medicine, page 839

questions.text: Which of the following is FDA approved agent used in the treatment of Ekbom's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Restless legs syndrome (RLS) also known as Ekbom syndrome is an uncomfortable, subjective sensation of the limbs, usually the legs, sometimes described as a 'creepy crawly' feeling, and the irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep. Patients often report the sensation of ants walking on the skin and crawling feelings in their legs. It tends to be worse at night and moving the legs or walking helps to alleviate the discomfort

Dopaminergic agonists pramipexole and ropinirole are FDA approved and represent the treatments of choice. Other agents used to treat RLS include dopamine precursors (e.g., levodopa), benzodiazepines, opiates, and antiepileptic drugs (e.g., gabapentin [Neurontin]). Nonpharmacological treatments include avoiding alcohol use close to bedtime, massaging the affected parts of the legs, taking hot baths, applying hot or cold to the affected areas, and engaging in moderate exercise.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 16, normal sleep and sleep wake disorders, page 559
